summary: This document is a subpoena filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorney, Jeffrey S. Pagliuca, to compel the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program (EVCP) to produce documents, communications, and releases related to accusers. It includes the subpoena form and the full protocol of the EVCP, detailing its voluntary, independent claims process administered by Kenneth R. Feinberg and Camille S. Biros, with consultation from Professor Marci A. Hamilton.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20CR330) for whom the subpoena is being requested by her defense attorney to obtain materials from the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell who requested and signed the subpoena to the EVCP from the law firm Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The individual whose estate established the compensation program for victims of his alleged sexual abuse. The program is designed to resolve claims against him and his estate.

persons.name: Kenneth R. Feinberg
persons.context: Nationally recognized claims administrator retained by the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein to help design the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program.

persons.name: Camille S. Biros
persons.context: Serves as the Administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, responsible for all decisions on claim eligibility and valuation.

persons.name: Marci A. Hamilton
persons.context: A professor and sexual abuse expert consulted by the Program Administrator to inform about abuse dynamics and victim sensitivities, and to review claimant files with consent.

connections.description: Pagliuca is the defense attorney representing Maxwell in the criminal case, as evidenced by him requesting the subpoena on her behalf.
The document references individuals who have accused both Epstein and Maxwell of misconduct, indicating their alleged association in the abuse.
Both were retained by the Epstein Estate to design and administer the Victims' Compensation Program.
The Program Administrator (Biros) may consult with Hamilton, a sexual abuse expert, to inform the claims evaluation process.
The Estate of Jeffrey Epstein retained Feinberg's services to design the compensation program.

events.title: Subpoena Issued to EVCP
events.description: Defense attorney Jeffrey S. Pagliuca issues a subpoena on behalf of Ghislaine Maxwell commanding the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program to produce documents, communications, and releases related to accusers.

events.title: EVCP Protocol Established
events.description: The Epstein Victims' Compensation Program Protocol is finalized, outlining the voluntary, independent process for victims to resolve claims against Jeffrey Epstein's estate.

locations: United States District Court, Southern District of New York, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007, Courtroom 318
Washington, D.C. 20035 (Mailing address for the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program)
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team subpoenaed the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program for all materials related to accusers, including claim forms, communications, payments, and releases.
The EVCP was a voluntary, independent program administered by Camille S. Biros, designed by Kenneth R. Feinberg, and could consult with expert Marci A. Hamilton.
The program allowed victims to file claims regardless of whether their claims were time-barred or if they had previously settled with Epstein.
Claimants who accepted compensation were required to sign a release waiving future claims against the Estate and related entities/individuals, but were not bound by confidentiality rules.
The subpoena demonstrates the defense's strategy to obtain information about accusers and the compensation process in Maxwell's criminal case.
